review.title: Part-of-Speech Tagging for Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text at ICON 2015
review.abstract: This paper discusses the experiments carried out by us at Jadavpur University as part of the participation in ICON 2015 task: POS Tagging for Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text. The tool that we have developed for the task is based on Trigram Hidden Markov Model that utilizes information from dictionary as well as some other word level features to enhance the observation probabilities of the known tokens as well as unknown tokens. We submitted runs for Bengali-English, Hindi-English and Tamil-English Language pairs. Our system has been trained and tested on the datasets released for ICON 2015 shared task: POS Tagging For Code-mixed Indian Social Media Text. In constrained mode, our system obtains average overall accuracy (averaged over all three language pairs) of 75.60% which is very close to other participating two systems (76.79% for IIITH and 75.79% for AMRITA_CEN) ranked higher than our system. In unconstrained mode, our system obtains average overall accuracy of 70.65% which is also close to the system (72.85% for AMRITA_CEN) which obtains the highest average overall accuracy.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Part of language (POS) tagging is the task of assigning grammatical categories (noun, verb, adjective, etc.) to words in a natural language sentence [1]. POS tagging can be used in various NLP (Natural Language Processing) applications. Interest in the application of NLP methods for analyzing non-standardized texts, such as social media texts, is growing rapidly [2], because the automatic analysis of social media texts is one of the essential prerequisites for the task of sentiment analysis [3]. Since social media texts contain blog comments or chat messages, it differs from standardized texts in word usage, but also in their grammatical structure. This creates the need for adaptation of NLP methods for analyzing social media texts and in particular for adapting POS tagging methods to such text types. Most state-of-the-art tagger texts have been developed for standardized text.

sections.heading: 2. PREPARATION OF TRAINING DATA
sections.text: The training data published for the ICON 2015 joint task contain three files: a file for Bengali-English language pairs, a file for Hindi-English language pairs, and a file for Tamil-English language pairs. Each line in a file contains tokens in the respective pair's languages, language tag, and part-of-speech tag. Participants are instructed to generate the output in the same format after testing the system based on the test data, where the test data per line includes a tab-separated token and the corresponding language tag. Our system uses a training file for a language pair and converts each sentence into a sequence of tokens and tags, each token in this new format being formed by combining the source token and some other information such as language tag. Details of this format will be discussed in later sections.

sections.heading: 4.1 Meta Tag
sections.text: Each token has some characteristics that distinguish one token from another. For example, a token may contain a "hash tag," which occurs frequently in social media text. Meta tag = "YYYY" (default), if the first character of the token is a hash symbol (#), then metatag = "HB," otherwise, if the hash tag exists in a different position of a token meta tag = "HE."

sections.heading: 4.2 Dictionary
sections.text: In previous sections, we have mentioned that we have also used some dictionary information as a meta tag. A meta tag is set to the value of a wide POS tag for a token after matching it with the dictionary words and retrieving the corresponding broad POS tag from the dictionary. A description of the dictionary is presented in Table 1. sections.heading: 5. EVALUATION AND RESULTS
sections.text: We train separately our developed POS taggers, which are based on the training data and define the parameters for the respective language pair. After learning the tuning parameters, we test our system on the test data for the respective language pair. The description of the data is presented in the tableaus, which are published by the organizers of the program.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper describes a POS tagging system for code-mixed social media text in Indian languages. Features such as dictionary-based information and some other word-level features were introduced into the HMM model. Experimental results show that the performance of our system is comparable to the best performing systems that participated in the ICON task 2015: POS tagging for code-mixed Indian social media text. The POS tagging system was developed on the basis of the Visual Basic platform so that a suitable user interface can be designed for beginners. The system was designed so that only changing the training corpus in one file can make the system portable to other Indian languages.
